item.title: 'sNice
item.regveg:long-description: <p>A trendy fair-trade organic coffee shop with many vegetarian menu items including vegan pot pie wrap, buffalo soy chicken wrap, and vegan pesto panini sandwiches. They also have vegan desserts and baked goods.</p>

item.title: 24 Carrots Organic Juice Bar
item.regveg:long-description: <p>24 Carrots Organic Juice Bar is completely vegetarian and 98% vegan. They have lots of juices, as the name implies, but they also serve a variety of desserts from BabyCakes and some raw food.</p>

item.title: 4th Street Food Co-op
item.regveg:directions:
The 4th Street Food Coop is located in the East Village, on 4th Street between Bowery and 2nd Avenue.
The 6, R, W, F, and V trains all stop within walking distance.
item.description: All-vegetarian natural foods cooperative market, open to public

item.title: Angelica Kitchen
item.regveg:long-description: <p>A small, pleasant place to get some tasty vegan food, especially desserts. Many of the options are light, though there are always a variety of choices. The menu has several Japanese-esque items, as well as vegan takes on traditional American food.</p>
item.description: Health vegan food in an earthy setting

item.title: Atlas Cafe
item.regveg:directions:
On 2nd Ave between 4th and 5th Streets.
The 6 at Bleecker Street or the F,V at Lower East Side/Second Ave subway stations are within 4 blocks.

item.title: Australian Homemade
item.regveg:directions: Between First Avenue and Avenue. Quick walk from Astor Place subway stop.
item.regveg:long-description: <p>Australian Homemade is a new shop on St. Marks Place between First Avenue and Avenue A. They offer premium ice cream made fresh in the store all-day, everyday, as well as handmade Belgian chocolates and coffee drinks like cappuccinos and lattes. All their product are all natural with no preservatives, flavorings or colors used.</p>

item.title: Ayurveda Cafe
item.regveg:long-description: <p>Ayurveda (which is a Sanskrit word meaning &quot;knowledge of life&quot;) is a 5,000-year old ancient Indian system of health and healing that’s become very popular recently through the popular writings of, among others, Deepak Chopra and Vasant Lad. The science stipulates a vegetarian diet with no eggs (dairy and honey is allowed and are, vegans beware, used liberally) and has to incorporate six tastes: sweet, sour, salty, astringent, bitter and pungent. The aim is to achieve balance for your body type—whether that’s tall and skinny, short and fat, medium build and fiery, or an elaborate combination of the three.</p> <p>One of the pleasures of Ayuveda Cafe is its simplicity. The lunch and dinner menus are both set for the day (they are different from each other). (For vegans, all entrées are cooked with vegetable oils, one need only steer clear of the raita.) There are two entrées (which can be okra- or lentil-based), a salad, chutneys, and rice (brown or basmati), raita (a yogurt), and nan bread. This is usually more than enough to eat, but if you need something more (and sweet) the desserts—including payasam and a sweet melon concoction—are delicious. You can also drink Indian spiced tea ($1.95), mango lassi ($2.50), and/or regular and decaffeinated coffee ($1.50).</p>

item.title: B & H Vegetarian Restaurant
item.regveg:long-description: <p>B &amp; H is a veg-friendly restaurant serving omelets, sandwiches, stews &amp; soups, salads, bakery, and random dishes like spaghetti, pizza, and....fish! They're a self-proclaimed vegetarian restaurant but they serve tons of fish. They do have vegan food, but it's mostly salad and steamed veggies with rice.</p> <p>The restaurant is very small and has about 3 tables and 8 chairs at a crowded counter. They can get pretty busy on the weekend but they do offer food to go.</p>

item.title: Babycakes NYC
item.regveg:directions:
Between Ludlow and Orchard.
By Subway: F/ J/ M/ Z at Delancey or the B/D to Grand Street
item.regveg:long-description: <p>Vegan Bakery that does not use: eggs, refined sugar, nuts, gluten, dairy, or wheat.</p> <p>Primarily carries in cupcakes, muffins, cookies, and drinks.</p>

item.title: Better Burger - Chelsea
item.regveg:long-description: <p>Fast food burger restaurant/café that caters to vegetarians/vegans as well as meat eaters. Everything is hormone free, antibiotic free and all natural. Veggie options include Veggie Burger, Soy Burger, Soy Dog, smoothies, Baked Fries, smashed potatoes, veggie chili, salads, and cookies. Condiments include vegan mayo, spiced wasabi sauce, and organic ketchup and mustard.</p>

item.title: Better Burger - Midtown West
item.regveg:long-description: <p>Fast food burger restaurant/café that caters to vegetarians/vegans as well as meat eaters. Everything is hormone free, antibiotic free and all natural. Veggie options include Veggie Burger, Soy Burger, Soy Dog, smoothies, Baked Fries, smashed potatoes, veggie chili, salads, and cookies. Condiments include vegan mayo, spiced wasabi sauce, and organic ketchup and mustard.</p>

item.title: Better Burger - Murray Hill
item.regveg:long-description: <p>Fast food burger restaurant/café that caters to vegetarians/vegans as well as meat eaters. Everything is hormone free, antibiotic free and all natural. Veggie options include Veggie Burger, Soy Burger, Soy Dog, smoothies, Baked Fries, smashed potatoes, veggie chili, salads, and cookies. Condiments include vegan mayo, spiced wasabi sauce, and organic ketchup and mustard.</p>

item.title: Better Burger - Upper East
item.regveg:long-description: <p>Fast food burger restaurant/café that caters to vegetarians/vegans as well as meat eaters. Everything is hormone free, antibiotic free and all natural. Veggie options include Veggie Burger, Soy Burger, Soy Dog, smoothies, Baked Fries, smashed potatoes, veggie chili, salads, and cookies. Condiments include vegan mayo, spiced wasabi sauce, and organic ketchup and mustard.</p>

item.title: Blossom
item.regveg:long-description: <p>Upscale vegan restaurant serving gourmet organic dinner. They also serve lunch &amp; brunch on Friday, Saturday &amp; Sunday 12-3.</p> <p>All ingredients are organic and the entire menu is 100% vegan from the eclectic appetizers to the delicious desserts. Situated in a 'townhouse' building, the feeling is chic, intimate and romantic without being cramped.</p>

item.title: Bonobo's Restaurant
item.regveg:directions: Across from Madison Square Park, between 5th Ave and Madison Ave.
item.regveg:long-description: <p>Deli style environs serving completely vegan, mostly organic, and raw foods.</p> <p>Sizable selection of juices, salads, and soups.</p>

item.title: Brick Lane Curry House
item.regveg:long-description: <p>Reputed to be a serious curry house. as standard Desi fare as well as Indian Beer. They claim to serve &quot;Real Curry.&quot; One item, the Phaal curry, requires a verbal confirmation and comes with a free bottle of beer if you finish it all.</p> <p>Nearly every item has a vegetable option. There is a good selection for v*gheads and omnivores.</p>

item.title: Buddha Bodai
item.regveg:directions: By train: Take the M, 6 train stop at City Hall Take the F train stop at Eastbroadway
item.regveg:long-description: <p>This Chinatown restaurant is described by some as the &quot;most authentic Chinese vegetarian restaurant&quot; in the United States. Rather than importing their mock meats like most restaurants, Buddha Bodai makes them all from scratch.</p>

item.title: Cafe Viva
item.regveg:long-description: <p>Cafe Viva serves kosher vegetarian food, mostly pizza, pasta and sandwiches. They have a number of vegan items, and have soy cheese for pizzas. They also have vegan desserts.</p> <p>They also offer wheat-free pizza crusts and pasta for folks with a wheat allergy.</p>

item.title: Candle 79
item.regveg:long-description: <p>Veg*n only macrobiotic and organic restaurant. Serves wines, beers, and has four courses available.</p>

item.title: Candle Cafe
item.regveg:long-description: <p>All of the food served here is vegan except for the soy cheese, which contains casein, and is always optional.</p>
item.description: Eclectic Mostly Vegan Restaurant on the Upper East Side

item.title: Caravan of Dreams
item.regveg:directions: Near the corner of 1st Ave & 6th St.
item.regveg:long-description: <p>Specializing in delicious and nutritious foods, Caravan of Dreams offers a varied menu and attentive service. The menu features multi-ethnic vegan dishes and a wide selection of raw, &quot;live&quot; dishes.</p>
item.description: 100% Vegan with a large "Live" food selection

item.title: Chennai Garden
item.regveg:directions: On 27th street, near the corner of Lexington.

item.title: Chickpea
Chikalicious
item.regveg:directions: Between 1st & 2nd Ave Near the Astor Place stop on 6 Subway Line

item.title: Cho Dang Gol
Counter
item.regveg:directions: Between 6th St. & 7th St. Subway: 6 Train to Astor Place F,V to lower east side/2nd avenue
item.regveg:long-description: <p>Vegetarian food using only the finest organic ingredients, including vegetables, fruit, herbs and edible flowers from Counter’s own roof top garden. Counter also has a selection of organic and bio-dynamic wines from around the world, a unique selection of organic Martinis made with house made infused vodka’s, and organic beers. </p> <p>Almost all of the food is vegan, including the desserts, though they do serve a few dishes with cheese, and the brunch menu includes a number of items with eggs.</p>
item.description: Organic Wine, Martinis, and Beer - Vegetarian Bistro

item.title: Curly's Vegetarian Lunch
item.regveg:long-description: <p>An all vegetarian diner where most things can be made vegan. Breakfast served all day, as well as burgers, sandwiches, salads, Mexican and desserts. Vegan or easily made vegan items are clearly labeled. Large dessert menu, most of which is vegan. They have fresh juices, as well as sodas, beer and wine.</p>

item.title: Delectica
item.regveg:long-description: <p>Delectica offers a variety of healthy dishes, including salads, platters, sandwiches, soups, smoothies, and desserts. The food is fresh and well prepared, and there are a number of vegetarian options.</p> <p>Delectica also provides catering for businesses and large parties.</p>

item.title: Dimple Indian Cuisine
item.regveg:directions: On West 30th between Broadway and 5th Avenue. The R and W lines let off on BBroadway and 28th, just a few blocks away, the 6 lets off at Park Ave and 33rd or 28th Street. Dimple is only 5 blocks from Herald Square, so any subway line that goes there will get you close enough.
item.description: Fast, cheap South Indian take out, eat in, and lunch buffet

item.title: Earthmatters
item.regveg:long-description: <p>Earthmatters is a natural market with a take-out counter offering a variety of prepared vegetarian foods. There is plenty of comfortable seating upstairs, as well as internet access.</p> <p>Earthmatters organic market was created to bring a change and a chance for better community life, these days where junk food is taking over everywhere we felt the need to bring you better and healthier foods. I have been taught that if we take care of each other we actually taking care of ourselves. At Earthmatters store we carry a collection of books that can give you much knowledge to bring us all closer to the source and to each other through the soul.</p>

item.title: Eastanah
item.regveg:long-description: <p>Borrowing influences from Chinese, Indian, and Thai cooking, the menu at Eastanah pleasantly defies definition. Knicknacks and artwork adorning the walls are like a crash course on Indonesian and Malaysian culture.</p>

item.title: Franchia Tea House & Restaurant
item.regveg:long-description: <p>Franchia is a Vegan-friendly tea house on Park Avenue, specializing in gourmet teas and Korean vegetarian food. Very special attention has been paid to the menu items, ranging from Vegan fondue to bamboo skewers with peanut sauce to Korean style sushi. They also have lunch time specialty wraps for a quick eat.</p> <p>A great deal of work has been put into the interior design with multi-tier levels to dine at. The location and décor makes it a popular lunch time spot for 9 to 5ers. They also have a tea shop in the front complete with a large variety of teas, teapots and cups.</p>
item.description: Posh Vegan-friendly Korean restaurant with eclectic menu and beautiful but sterile environment.

item.title: Frites & Beignettes
item.regveg:long-description: <p>Robins-egg blue Euro-trendy space serving up both vegetarian and non-vegetarian versions of central European street food, like dogs in buns with various sauces, a variety of fries, beverages, and desserts.</p>

item.title: Galaxy Global Eatery
item.regveg:long-description: <p>The Galaxy Global Eatery... is about Global cuisine - taking the most flavorful and innovative culinary ideas and ingredients from all over our world to produce a new and fresh cuisine that's delicious, never boring and always engaging.</p> <p>We are a progressive establishment committed to living in harmony with the planet. One important aspect of this commitment is to raise consciousness relating to the hemp plant. Industrial hemp is a highly nutritious food and a practical source of fiber, paper pulp, board and cloth.</p>

item.title: Gobo
item.regveg:long-description: <p>An eclectic eatery featuring an open kitchen, an organic juice bar, and global cuisine.</p> <p>Call 212.288.5099 for delivery and take out orders.</p>

item.title: Gobo
item.description: Gourmet Asian in the West Village

item.title: Hangawi
item.regveg:long-description: <p>Hangawi is a posh vegan Korean restaurant, and is an oasis of calm in mid-town Manhattan. Diners take off their shoes and sit low to the floor on cushions.</p> <p>The cuisine is gourmet Korean with various traditional foods represented, including such things as pumpkin porridge or the delicate Emperor's rolls.</p>
item.description: Vegan Korean dining in a tranquil space

item.title: Health Conscious Express
item.regveg:directions: Health Conscious Express is on 1st Avenue between 2nd and 3rd Streets. The F & V trains stop at the LES station on Houston between 1st and 2nd, a few blocks away.
item.description: Ital food and juice in the East Village

item.title: House of Vegetarian
item.regveg:long-description: <p>I think it's all vegan (though not certain). Huge menu. Many fake meats as well as many all vegetable dishes. </p>

item.title: Il Laboratorio del Gelato
item.regveg:directions:
Between Broome and Delancey.
Orchard is parallel between Ludlow and Allen. This means north of Canal, but east of the Bowery.
item.regveg:long-description: <p>Small, storefront selling ice creams and sorbets from a rotating roster of over 70 flavors. Committed to using local and/or organic sources.</p>

item.title: Integral Yoga Natural Foods
item.regveg:long-description: <p>Vegetarian and natural grocery store that has TONS of vegan options. They have a wide variety of bulk, fresh, and packaged products and also feature a salad bar with sandwiches, soups, salads, and a hot buffet table.</p>

item.title: JivamukTea Cafe
item.regveg:long-description: <p>Opened in May 2006, this Yoga center features a Vegan Cafe.</p>

item.title: Josie's East
Josie's West
Jubb's Longevity
item.regveg:long-description: <p>Jubb's Longevity sells herbal remedies and health products related to live food lifestyle. There is a take-out counter where they prepare a variety of live food dishes and desserts.</p>

item.title: Kate's Joint
item.regveg:long-description: <p>It is junk food for Veg*ns. They have philly uncheese unsteak, fried unchicken with mashed potatoes and gravy, and all sorts of Veg*ned diner food. Everything is available with a cheese alternative. Be prepared for a lot of deep fried items.</p> <p>They also have a brunch on the weekends.</p>

item.title: Lan Cafe
item.regveg:long-description: <p>All vegan restaurant (though I think their Vietnamese coffee is not) in the East Village. The menu includes appetizers, soups, salads, baguette sandwiches and fake meats. They've even got a veg version of Pho.</p>

item.title: Life Cafe
item.regveg:long-description: <p>&quot;The sidewalk café provides the perfect vantage point to take in the constant parade, the pulse and vibe of East Village life. In contrast, our secret garden is an intimate and magical hideaway known to few and treasured by many.&quot; Not vegetarian, but an excellent tofu scramble and a few other vegan options.</p>

item.title: LifeThyme Vegan Bakery
item.regveg:long-description: <p>LifeThyme is an all-vegan, kosher, organic bakery located inside the LifeThyme Natural Market. LifeThyme offers chocolate chip Toll Booth cookies, Tiramisu, seasonal pies, pudding and a huge range of cakes, including a variety of raw cakes and desserts.</p>

item.title: Little Lad's Basket
Madras Cafe
item.regveg:long-description: <p>Everything is vegetarian. Vegan items are clearly marked. Dosas can be made with spinach or vegetables in addition to the normal filling. There is a dinner special that includes soup, rice, bread. choice of 2 entrees and desert for around $10, otherwise it is great to go with many people and share items.</p>

item.title: Mamoun's Falafel
item.regveg:long-description: <p>Mamoun's is a Middle-Eastern take-out restaurant famous for its falafel. The original location is near Washington Square Park.</p>

item.title: Maoz Vegetarian Restaurant
item.regveg:directions: Between 16th and 17th Streets. Take L,N,R,Q,W,4,5,6 to 14th Street-Union Square.
item.regveg:long-description: <p>Maoz Vegetarian is an all-vegetarian (and nearly all vegan) falafel shop that features falafel sandwiches, salads, and fries. After you get your sandwich, there's a large selection of self-serve toppings - pickles, cucumber salad, roasted cauliflower, dairy and vegan coleslaws, carrots, baby eggplants dyed in beet juice (really), olives, several fresh hot sauces, and much more. The trick is they don't leave very much spare room in your sandwich, so you can't really load up on the condiments.</p> <p>The first Maoz branch was opened in 1991 in Amsterdam, Holland in order to introduce Dutch people to a new and nutritious vegetarian dish (falafel sandwiches). The Maoz sandwich became a huge success in Amsterdam, leading to the expansion of Maoz both nationally and internationally.</p>

item.title: May Wah Vegetarian Grocery
item.regveg:directions: Between Centre St and Baxter St, 1 block North of Canal St. 1 block from #6 train.
item.regveg:long-description: <p>May Wah has almost every kind of meat substitute imaginable. It is a small store, but I guarantee you will find whatever kind of Chinese meat substitute you are looking for. Almost all of it is also Vegan. They also stock some soups and sauces. </p> <p>The staff is very friendly and helpful. They will also ship anywhere. Check out their website for ordering info.</p>
item.description: Asian grocery mostly stocking frozen meat substitutes.

item.title: Moo Shoes
item.regveg:directions: Take the F train to 2nd Avenue. Just north of Rivington Street. It looks like you're in the middle of nowhere on Allen Street, but keep going - you'll find Moo shoes on the East side of the street.

item.title: NY Dosas
item.regveg:directions:
NY Dosas is at the south edge of Washington Square Park, by the corner of Washington Square South and Sullivan Street.
The W. 4th St. (A,B,C,D,E,F,V), 8th St. (R,W), and Astor Place (6) subway stations are all within a few blocks.
item.description: All vegan South Indian food in Washington Square Park

item.title: Oms/b
item.regveg:directions: On 45th Street between Lexington and Third Avenue. Very close to the Grand Central Station
item.regveg:long-description: <p>Tiny cafe serving set lunches, snacks, and dinners. Primarily in the form of rice balls, they have several vegetarian and vegan options. These rice balls break the traditional mold, and use a multitude of fusion type ingredients.</p> <p>The vegan Hijiki is soya skin wrapped around a triangle of pressed rice, mixed with edamame and hijiki. There is a small selection of teas as well as prepackaged beverages.</p>

item.title: Organic Avenue
item.regveg:long-description: <p>Organic Avenue offers the most incredible Hemp &amp; Organic Clothing, Raw Food Staple Products, Fresh Live Organic Produce, Raw Food Classes, Gourmet Raw Dinners, Conscious Events, Holistic Healing Retreats, and much, much, more!</p> <p>For more information, to sign up for Organic Avenue's 100% Living: eNewsletter, to place an order, or to become a member, contact: Organic Avenue @ 212.334.4593 or email: Info@OrganicAvenue.com</p>

item.title: Organic Harvest Cafe
Ozu
item.regveg:long-description: <p>Organic and Macrobiotic Japanese restaurant serving vegetarian and vegan friendly fare. Several grains, kelp dishes, greens, noodles, &amp; sushi. They serve no dairy, but serve some fish.</p>

item.title: Planet One Cafe
item.regveg:long-description: <p>All vegetarian, mostly vegan. Soups, sandwiches, jamaican vegetable patties, rice, greens, pasta, pies and more. Very friendly and accommodating. I think everything is made by one woman.</p>
item.description: Tiny Veg Cafe in East Village

item.title: Pongal Indian Cuisine - Midtown East
Pongal Indian Cuisine - Murray Hill
Pukk
item.regveg:long-description: <p>Pukk is an all vegetarian Thai restaurant with many vegan options.</p>
item.description: Vegetarian Thai food in the East Village

item.title: Punjabi
item.regveg:long-description: <p>Punjabi's menu completely vegetarian and mostly vegan. It serves cheap Indian food and it's open 24 hours a day, 7 days a week.</p> <p>Note that Punjabi only accepts cash and they have only counter service (no seats).</p>

item.title: Pure Food and Wine
item.regveg:long-description: <p>Completely vegan raw food restaurant. Open air garden dining. Also available are vegan wines, processed without any animal products.</p> <p>Serving fusion fresh foods, all prepared in manners keeping food under 118 degrees Fahrenheit.</p>

item.title: Pure Food and Wine To Go
item.regveg:long-description: <p>Completely vegan raw food and juices to go. </p> <p>Serving fusion fresh foods, this take away version of Pure Food also has baked goods and ice creams. Selection of smoothies, snacks, and vegan products.</p>

item.title: Quintessence
item.regveg:long-description: <p>Nothing is heated above 118 Fahrenheit. Varied selection of appetizers, salads, soups, entrees, and &quot;guiltless&quot; desserts.</p> <p>They use nut milks, nori, flax crackers, nut patees, sprouted wild rice, and so forth.</p>

item.title: Quintessence - Amsterdam Ave.
item.regveg:long-description: <p>Quintessence Restaurant is a completely vegan restaurant. Nothing is heated above 118 Fahrenheit. It has a varied selection of appetizers, salads, soups, entrees, and &quot;guiltless&quot; desserts.</p>

item.title: Radha Vegetarian Restaurant
item.regveg:long-description: <p>Radha Restaurant is a vegetarian international and Indian restaurant. They can also host private parties or meetings. Note that they are not open for lunch, but they are open really late on Thursday, Friday, and Saturday.</p>

item.title: Raw Soul
item.regveg:long-description: <p>Raw Soul, owned by a veg couple, is a vegetarian juice bar and restaurant serving raw food and drinks. Their meals are prepared fresh daily with local fruits and vegetables from scratch. They do not use any dairy, refined sugars, tofu, preservatives, or processed foods. They have a lunch special every day for $9.</p>

item.title: ReBoot
item.regveg:directions: Between 3rd and 4th on Ave. A in the E. Village, Manhattan.
item.regveg:long-description: <p>This foundation of the east village pizza scene is going vegan (only the original restaurant on A and 3rd, not the TwoBoots &quot;complex&quot; across the street). Currently, they're still offering the non-vegan pizzas that put the place on the map, but have added about 20 new items that are all vegan. The pizzas are going to be phased out as their customers get used to the &quot;rebooted&quot; menu, which includes about 1/2 raw foods.</p>

item.title: Red Bamboo
item.regveg:long-description: <p>Red Bamboo is owned and operated by the folks a few doors down at Vegetarian Paradise 2. While VP2 is more of your typical asian fake meat type place, Red Bamboo takes a more soul food approach while still keeping a bit of asian influence. Great appetizers include the Spiced Jerk Chicken and the Cajun Fried Shrimp. For entrees, try the Grilled Bourbon Chicken, the Citrus Beef, or the incredible &quot;Dante's Cuisine.&quot; </p> <p>They serve a small, but high quality selection of red and white wines (about half are organic), about a dozen beers (3-5 organic ones), lots of juices and real cherry cokes. </p>
item.description: A vegan soul food/asian fusion oasis

item.title: Rice
item.regveg:long-description: <p>Rice based menu carries many international selections of rice: rice and beans, basmati, thai, green, and bhutanese.</p> <p>You may choose many optional sides to dress up your rice, but care should be taken in ensuring they are veg*n.</p>
item.description: Vegetarian friendly, rice based style cuisine

item.title: Rice - Lexington
item.regveg:long-description: <p>Rice based menu carries many international selections of rice: rice and beans, basmati, Thai, green, and Bhutanese.</p> <p>You may choose many optional sides to dress up your rice, but care should be taken in ensuring they are veg*n.</p>
item.description: Vegetarian friendly, rice based style cuisine

item.title: Sacred Chow
item.regveg:long-description: <p>A small vegan bakery, deli, and juice / smoothie bar located in the west village. </p> <p>Mostly a take out place, but there are a few tables for customers.</p>

item.title: Saigon 48
item.regveg:long-description: <p>Saigon 48 is a veg-friendly Vietnamese restaurant in Midtown. They feature a &quot;design your own&quot; veg dish where you can specify up to four of your favorite vegetarian ingredients for the dish.</p>

item.title: Sanctuary
item.regveg:long-description: <p>Veg*n food with karma. About 80% of the food is vegan.</p>

item.title: Shake Shack
item.regveg:directions: Closest to Madison Ave and 23rd St.
item.description: Burgers and Shakes @ Madison Square Park

item.title: Soba Ya
item.regveg:directions: Between 2nd Ave and 3rd Ave. Specifically, one street north of St Marks, between 2nd and Stuyvesant.
item.regveg:long-description: <p>They make their own Soba (Buckwheat) Noodles. There is a vegan and vegetarian option.</p>

item.title: Souen
item.regveg:long-description: <p>Serving organic, macrobiotic fare with Asian accents in a warm, soothing atmosphere for the past 20 years, with pretty lighting, light pastel walls and bunches of dried flowers. Starters include tahini noodles, tempeh with ginger vegetable sauce, tofu scrambled with scallions and carrots, and vegetable tempura. There are quite a few larger seafood and vegetarian courses, obento boxes and sushi, and sides of organic whole grain breads, steamed greens, homemade pickles, and marinated burdock root. Nutritious breakfast specials are served from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m., and even the drinks are healthy, with fresh-squeezed juices, organic coffee and wines. Souen is a place that specializes in an American cuisine known for their vegetarian meals. Expect the average entrée to cost roughly $12 to $20, and you'll be fine if dressed casual.</p>

item.title: Soy Luck Club
item.regveg:long-description: <p>A stylish and casual hangout in the West Village (with free wi-fi access). A variety of soy milk drinks (hot and cold) in flavors like honey and ginger, dark chocolate, vanilla and caramel. Soy Luck Club also serves sandwiches, salads, desserts, and omelettes</p>
item.description: Vegan Cafe with Love for Soy

item.title: Spring Street Natural
item.regveg:long-description: <p>Spring Street Natural Restaurant was founded in 1973 in the heart of SoHo. The Restaurant quickly became a neighborhood fixture, serving up fresh, healthy cuisine at affordable prices to local denizens. In 1985 Spring Street Natural moved east to the corner of Spring and Lafayette. Tripling our space and adding abundant sunlight and windows, Spring Street Natural blossomed at this new corner location along with the surrounding area in what has become a vibrant neighborhood on the convergent edge of SoHo and NoLIta.</p> <p>Now in our fourth decade of serving healthy natural cuisine we believe we have finally hit our stride. We offer a wide range of choices from completely vegan macrobiotic plates to sandwiches, salads, and innovative entrees with vegetarian, seafood and poultry choices. Be sure to check out our daily specials and join us for weekend Brunch, enjoy.</p>

item.title: Strictly Roots
item.regveg:directions:
Strictly Roots is at the corner of Adam Clayton Powell Jr Blvd (7th Avenue) and 123rd Street.
The 125th Street stops of the 2, 3, A, B, C, and D lines are all within a few blocks.

item.title: Sukhadia's Gokul
item.regveg:directions: On 45th Street between Fifth Avenue and Sixth Avenue. Near 7 at the Fifth Ave./Bryant Park subway stop and B, D, F, and V at the 42nd St.-Bryant Park subway stop.
item.regveg:long-description: <p>Sukhadia's has many traditional Indian favorites and unique specialties, including a wide selection of north Indian and South Indian dishes and sweets.</p>

item.title: Sukhadia's Indian Vegetarian Restaurant
Tam
Teany
item.regveg:long-description: <p><strong>Currently Closed</strong></p> <p>They are restructuring. They will potentially reopen in Feb 2006 as a tea shop only.</p>

item.title: Temple in the Village
item.regveg:directions: Between Laguardia and Thompson, just south of Washington Square Park.
item.regveg:long-description: <p>A macrobiotic buffet filled with vegan and vegetarian items. Your plate is weighed at the end, and is currently $6/lb.</p> <p>Close to Washington Square Park.</p>

item.title: The Organic Grill
Tibetan Kitchen
item.regveg:directions: Between 30th and 31st, next to the library.
item.regveg:long-description: <p>Small restaurant run by a Tibetan family. They serve a half vegetarian menu. Most entrees are under $10. They have Momo (dumplings), and hearty vegetarian soups, which are really more like stews. They also have bocha, the traditional salted butter tea.</p>

item.title: Tien Garden
item.regveg:long-description: <p>Buddhist chinese (no onions, garlic, leeks, shallot &amp; tobacco..(yes it says that!)) and some sandwich and salad items. Small restaurant. Friendly atmosphere. </p>

item.title: Tiny's Giant Sandwich Shop
item.regveg:long-description: <p>Although this vegetarian-friendly sandwich shop is small in size, its veggie burger has been met with much acclaim, winning PETA's Golden Bun Award for Best Hometown Veggie Burger.</p>
item.description: Sandwich shop with many vegetarian options

item.title: Una Pizza Napoletana
item.regveg:directions: Between 1st and 2nd Ave. L train to 1st Ave.

item.title: Uptown Juice Bar
item.regveg:directions:
The Uptown Juice Bar is in the heart of the Harlem's commercial district, on 125th Street (aka Martin Luther King Blvd) between Lenox Ave (aka Malcolm X Blvd) and 5th Ave.
The 2 and 3 subway lines let off half a block away, and the ABCD and 456 lines all let off on 125th Street within 3 or 4 blocks.
item.description: All-vegan Caribbean and Soul Food in Harlem

item.title: Vatan
Vegetarian Dim Sum House
item.regveg:long-description: <p>This place is ridiculous (ly good). For those of us veggies who once tasted dim sum but never got to return to this realm of delight because of its unavoidable meaty potential, this is your dream come true. Great prices. Astoundingly yummy selections. If you choose to order from the non-dim sum menu, this will do you well, too. My favorite: Treasure Balls. (Don't ask, don't tell.) </p> <p><strong>Please note it is CASH ONLY</strong></p>
item.description: Delicious all vegan dim sum in the heart of Chinatown.

item.title: Vegetarian's Paradise 2 (VP2)
item.regveg:long-description: <p>The menu here primarily features veg*n Chinese dishes, but also has a fairly large selection of veg meat based dishes. Some of their dishes include fried &quot;chicken&quot;, curries, Singapore noodles, citrus beef, and more. There's something for everyone.</p>
item.description: Vegetarian Chinese restaurant in the West Village

item.title: Viva Herbal Pizzeria
item.regveg:directions: Between 11th and 12th streets. Take the L train to 1st or 3rd Ave.
item.regveg:long-description: <p>Viva Herbal Pizzeria (sometimes called Cafe Viva) serves kosher vegetarian food, mostly pizza, pasta and sandwiches. They have a number of vegan items, and have soy cheese (not-vegan) for pizzas. They also have vegan desserts from Vegan Treats.</p> <p>They also offer wheat-free pizza crusts and pasta for folks with a wheat allergy.</p>

item.title: Westerly Natural Market
item.regveg:long-description: <p>Westerly Natural Market offers a huge selection of nutritional supplements, organic produce, all natural groceries, environmentally friendly body care products to our customers at the most affordable prices. Our knowledgeable staff will go out of their way to ensure that you are completely satisfied.</p>

item.title: Whole Earth Bakery & Kitchen
item.regveg:long-description: <p>Small vegan bakery in the East Village that makes muffins, breads, cookies, pies, cheese cakes as well as soups, turnovers, sandwiches and other specialties. Mostly a take-out place with a small bar to eat at. Many wheat free, sugar free, oil free options. No refined sugars, honey, margarine or hydrogenated fats.</p>

item.title: Whole Foods Market
item.regveg:long-description: <p>Whole Foods is a well-known national food store that is famous for using no trans-fats in any of its products. It has a wide selection of vegetarian, vegan, and organic food.</p>
item.description: Whole Foods Market in Union Square

item.title: Whole Foods Market
item.regveg:long-description: <p>Whole Foods is a well-known national food store that is famous for using no trans-fats in any of its products. It has a wide selection of vegetarian, vegan, and organic food.</p>

item.title: Whole Foods Market
item.regveg:long-description: <p>Whole Foods is a well-known national food store that is famous for using no trans-fats in any of its products. It has a wide selection of vegetarian, vegan, and organic food.</p>

item.title: Wild Ginger Vegetarian Kitchen
item.regveg:directions: 380 Broome Street, between Mott and Mulberry. Number Six subway line to Spring Street stop. Exit Spring St. Station at Lafayette St. Two blocks east to Mulberry St. Two block south to Broome St.
item.regveg:long-description: <p>Just opened. Pan-Asian cuisine, 95% vegan, moderately priced, in the heart of Little Italy. Intimate ambiance. Take-out is available from noon to 11PM, midnight on weekends.</p>
item.description: Gourmet Pan-Asian cuisine, 95% Vegan, moderately priced

item.title: Woo Lae Oak SoHo
item.regveg:long-description: <p>Upscale Korean restaurant that has something for everyone.</p> <p>This has rich options for vegans and their nonvegan friends, served in an environment with high service and no communication problems. </p>

item.title: Yaffa Cafe
item.description: Great veggie options, plus lovely patio in back, beer and wine and herbal teas available

item.title: Zen Palate - Financial District
item.regveg:long-description: <p>Zen Palate's menu, most of which is vegan, is composed of a diverse mixture of Eastern and Western ingredients and New York fusion cooking. Rather than buying processed ingredients from manufacturers, they produce most of their foods on site from daily-fresh vegetables and fruits.</p>

item.title: Zen Palate - Theatre District
item.regveg:directions: At 46th St. Near A, C, E at 8th Ave and 42nd Street
item.regveg:long-description: <p>Zen Palate's menu is composed of a diverse mixture of Eastern and Western ingredients and New York fusion cooking. Rather than buying processed ingredients from manufacturers, they produce most of their foods on site from daily-fresh vegetables and fruits.</p>

item.title: Zen Palate - Union Square
item.regveg:long-description: <p>This is one of three Zen Palate restaurants in New York. There are two parts to this restaurant. The downstairs is a more casual cheaper restaurant. The upstairs is a gourmet fancy restaurant. It has many unique appetizers and entrees to choose from, as well as a few deserts. There are also non-alcoholic drinks and tonics. No alcohol is served in the restaurant.</p>
item.description: Gourmet vegan food with a Chinese influence.

item.title: Zenith Vegetarian Restaurant
item.regveg:long-description: <p>This is an all-vegetarian establishment, but they share their space with a sushi bar that serves fish. The sushi bar is at the front of the establishment and you walk through it to get to Zenith (there's no walls in between the two dining spaces) but it's the only vegetarian restaurant in Times Square.</p> <p>They offer an eclectic array of vegetarian dishes (mostly vegan) and offer various veggies, faux meats, and lots of lunch specials. You also get a coupon for free wine with every purchase over $10, which you can redeem on your next visit.</p>

channel.title: VegGuide.Org: Manhattan
channel.description: Data feed of entries for Manhattan, New York City.
